Also, I think it helps to overstate the significance of xor gates essentially being single bit binary adders. To me, that helps acknowledge where that actual adding process is occurring in the circuit. You move up the level of abstraction too quickly here. Also, I know you come back to it after, but it's really not initially apparent where the first C input comes from in the full adder.   v=VPw9vPN-3ac  maybe this will help people if they want to go through it again slowly before moving past the full adder and actually understanding it. Briefly The Kinks and Steely Dan were right.  Do It Again.  Logic starts out with Small Scale Integration (SSI).  A bunch of NAND gates limited by the number of pins on the package.  As technology improves we go to Medium Scale Integration (MSI).  An 8 bit counter for instance.  Technology improves some more and we go to Large Scale Integration (LSI).  Then VLSI.  Then a totally new technology comes out in SSI.  Then goes to MSI, LSI and VLSI.  ALU's may seem old hat, but with Field Programmable Gate Arrays and other programmable logic, they become core components in a library.  All of sudden every minute detail of this design is important again.  A newer technology will then come along. Do It Again.

based on my own puzzlement, i believe, that it's worth to emphasize/notice at this (4:22) point, that the two carriers are never equal to 1 simultaneously, otherwise we would lose one bit in this case. this follows from the fact, that the carrier in the half adder is equal to 1 if and only if both its inputs are equal to 1, at which point its sum is equal to 0. and since the sum of the left adder is the a input of the right adder we get our conclusion.

Nowadays, you have dedicated circuitry which handles division. But in the old days you had to compute A/B by counting how often you could subtract B from A without the result becoming negative. You don't need any special circuitry for subtracting numbers because you can use the same circuitry as for addition. As you can imagine, that is not exactly an efficient way to compute division.

Well, this is a crash course after all. These are complicted topics, and this is only an overview. The best way to learn this is taking notes and then researching the topics that seem complicated one by one. You also should start experimenting, there is a very good circuit Electroinc Circuit simulator online (The first one that apears when you search on google for "falstad simuator") which you can use to start experimenting with transistors and how to use them to build logic gates. Then you can start working with logic gates themselves using something like the AMAZING "Gateway Logic Simulator" that more people should know about, it's a FREE circuit simlator that let's you create custom component, just like what this series does with levels of abstraction. You literaly can follow the whole logic part of the course with that simulator and end up with a complete 8 bit CPU. On the other hand, if you don't know how to program i REALLY recomend you looking into the Processing and P5.js. They have an amazing comunity, a lot of tutorials and examples (The Youtube Chanel Coding Train is pure gold). They are designed with beginers in mind, and are completely graphics oriented, you can even use them to program the 3d engine from later on. Oh, and one final recomendation is to start using linux, at least in a virtual machine, or with the Windows Linux Subsystem on Windows 10. Linux is super friendly with developers, and it's also amazing for networking and hacking. Heck, if you want to program in C on windows you'll probably have to install Visual Studio. That's a 10Gb+ download, and in the end you wouldn't know what's going on with the compiler under the hood at all. While on linux you have the most used C compiler (GCC) preinstalled and ready to go (And yeah, just like all the other software i recomended, linux is a completely free OS). So yeah, those are my little tips. If you decide to go down this rabbit hole, you will learn a lot of amazing stuff and will create a lot of beautifull things. But you have to stay determined, never be afraid of admiting that you don't undestand something, and have the to learn it. May StackOverflow be with you

The process isn't correct.  Take 7 - 0.  A = 7. B = 0. A in binary is 0111. B in binary is 0000.  B inverted is 1111. Adding A + B yields 10111 or in the process you described, -7.  Moreover, this process introduces a lot of unnecessary logic and has an issue of 2 versions of 0.  The actual answer is to use 2's complement arithmetic.  It's best described by searching for computerphile 2's compliment in youtube.  But the gist behind 2's complement is that the most significant bit represents -(2 raised to that places power).  For example if we have a 4 bit system, the largest negative number is -2^3 = -8.  So with this system you can represent the numbers from 1000 to 0111 or -8 to 7 and you only have one version of 0.  Plus get the result boils down to simple addition with no concern over the carry representing sign since sign is built into the number.  So with 2's complement addition our example of 7-0 becomes 0111 + 0000 = 0111 = 7.  Or for another example of 3 - 7 becomes 0011 + 1001 = 1100 = -4.

Knowing hardware is integral to being a good computer scientist/programmer/engineer.   CrashCourse touched on this topic a bit but decimal numbers can't be represented perfectly on hardware. This is about floating point precision.   The following Java code gives an unexpected result:  public class NumericalPrecisionTest {   public static void main(String[] args) {     double cnt = 0.0;     for (int i = 0; i < 1000; i++) {       cnt += 0.01;     }     System.out.println(cnt);   } }  // expected: 1000 x 0.01 = 10 // actual: 9.999999999999831  This has many real-world consequences (think anything financial related). What about irrational numbers like pi?  Another example. I was reading a stack overflow thread a few hours ago where someone got a 20x speedup by sorting an array before iterating through it. That goes against everything you learn in an algorithms course and common sense in general.   So how is it possible to get a 20x speedup by performing more work? Because branch prediction (e.g. design of computer architecture). OP got a recommendation (after a ton of discussion and research) to remove the sorting routine and slightly modify an if expression and BOOM instant gains.  The above are examples of why you learn system hardware while taking CS in University. It's pretty damn important!  LINKS:  What Every Computer Scientist Should Know About Floating-Point Arithmetic https://docs.oracle.com/cd/E19957-01/806-3568/ncg_goldberg.html  What every programmer should know about memory https://lwn.net/Articles/250967/  BONUS QUESTION: Given a square n-by-n matrix, how would you loop throw the elements?  HINT: This has to do with how computers retrieve values from memory and how computer languages are implemented (for example you will get a different answer if you use R vs c).

Just a note: In most architectures (x86 included), the overflow bit is for SIGNED overflow. The carry bit is in a flag marked carry or unsigned overflow. This distinction is extremely important and the cause of many subtle bugs for new assembly programmers.  Thus the flags are Z (zero), C (carry), O (Overflow), S (Sign). There are many more (depending on the cpu), but you need these to be able to handle the inequality conditionals correctly for both signed and unsigned integers.

By the way, the inversion is nothing flipping all bits (either through a simple NOT or an XOR) and then add to the value by one.

Flipping bits and adding 1 is not the way to do subtraction since it will lead to 2 versions of 0 and introduces unnecessary logic.  The actual way is to use 2's complement numbers where you embed negative numbers inside the binary representation.  The most significant bit becomes -(2 raised to place of that power).  So if you had a 4 bit device, the lowest number it could represent would be -2^(4-1) = -2^(3) = -8.  Negative numbers just become -8 + whatever is to the right of that number.  So 1011 = -8 + 2 + 1 = -5.  When numbers are represented in 2's complement, subtraction and addition just become addition.

"They are defined through programs written in a programming language" Not necessarily. With an FPGA (Field Programmable Gate Array) one can build custom hardware architectures for the implementation of an specific algorithm using logic gates and some good old sequential logic. Now, if one is using the FPGA as a hardware accelerator, it is possible to use a program in a programming language to feed and receive data into the FPGA, however the whole point of it is that this program will only give it the ones and zeros of the data and some configurations, and the actual algorithm will be executed by the custom architecture.

verdatum Yes, but VHDL and Verilog are not programming languages, they are hardware description languages. Even if they have some behavioural synthesis options, after you compile your code you end up with a bitsteram that is sent via jtag and configures the registries in the  LUTs to implement your architecture.

As a side note to those wondering how subtraction is done, it is also done through addition. The way computers store negative integers in binary is a system called 2's complement, which is difficult to discuss in a short text comment, but it allows the addition of a positive integer X and a negative integer Y to equal X - Y. If you want to subtract Y from X you just turn Y into a negative number (which is a very fast operation) and then add them together.

+Preeth Kaveri The problem here is that you 1111 is -1 in 2's compliment and 1010 is -6. if we are dealing with only 4 bits. It is a little complicated to intuitively understand, which is why I didn't explain it very much in my comment.   Going with that very specific example, if we want to subtract either 10 from 15 (which I think was your intent), we are going to use a 5 bit number, because signed 4 bit numbers only gives us a range of -8 to 7. So, if we want to subtract 1010 from 1111, we need to first turn these into 5 bit numbers. So, we have 01010 and 01111. Next, we realize that we want to subtract 01010, so we will make it negative. Taking the two's compliment gives us 10110. Now, we add this to our 01111 which gives us 100101. This, you may notice, is a 6 bit number. Whenever it overflows, we just get rid of it, which gives us 00101. If you look at what we were doing in decimal, we did 15 - 10, which should be 5. Our answer is 5, so we did it correctly.  The question of course may be why does this work?
